awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Worker-in-the-loop real time safety system for short-duration highway workzones
awd_abstract_narration:
This project proposes a novel safety system that enables real-time prediction for safety risks near highway work zones, through recent advances in Artificial Intelligence (AI). The proposed safety system provides real-time notification to highway workers through smart glasses when a work zone intrusion is about to happen. In particular, this project focuses on short-duration highway work zones which cause higher safety risks due to lack of proper safety mechanisms. This project enhances the health and prosperity of the nation by making highways safer places for workers and preventing potential fatalities or injuries caused by highway work zones.

This project departs from existing reactive safety systems to a true proactive safety system. It makes fundamental contributions in real-time deep learning algorithm design and processing, edge computing, and assisted reality systems to enable real-time prediction of work zone intrusions and notification of highway workers. The proposed worker-in-the-loop safety system will be co-designed and co-created with the direct help of highway work zone workers, leading industries, and human factors experts to identify the best feedback mechanisms for alarming workers regarding upcoming safety risks. This project will play a key role in the development of the next generation cyber-physical systems with powerful edge computing for many emerging safety and security-related applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) reports that from 2017 to 2021, there were 4,374 fatalities and 208,000 injuries in work zones across the US, with a staggering 956 fatalities in 2021 alone. This project leveraged the recent advances in machine learning, real-time data analytics, and edge computing combined with augmented reality to enhance the safety of short-duration highway work zones and make highway work zones a safer place for workers. This project developed an ensemble of novel technologies, including (1) Real-time AI-empowered sensor-fusion analytics to capture reckless driving behaviors near the work zone and (2) a Worker-in-the-loop system that utilizes smart glasses and direct wireless communication technology for real-time alarming/notification. At the same time, this project developed a systematic approach to engage the broader highway workforce community engagement to understand the impact of our worker-in-the-loop safety system on workforce performance, operational efficiency, and overall acceptance. The end-to-end AI pipeline suited for edge-based embedded devices has provided a new platform for work-zone-based safety applications that can produce real-time results. It provides real-time AI-based feedback to workers, winning them a few extra seconds to take appropriate action for their safety. 

This project curated a comprehensive highway-based vehicle dataset for tracking and trajectory prediction in real-world scenarios. It introduced a state-of-the-art trajectory prediction algorithm using multiple point-of-view datasets, achieving unparalleled accuracy. The project proposed an anomaly detection system tailored to highway vehicles, enhancing safety measures. It developed an end-to-end AI framework for real-world, real-time highway safety applications, encompassing detection, tracking, trajectory prediction, and anomaly detection. Additionally, the project evaluated the impact of augmented reality warnings on workers' reaction times in outdoor and virtual reality environments, developed a high-fidelity virtual reality testbed for highway work zones, and successfully tested the framework on multiple embedded platforms, demonstrating its edge applicability and integration with existing infrastructure.

The project resulted in high-impact research products. A new patent was granted for the proposed research, with the title of "WORKER-IN-THE-LOOP REAL TIME SAFETY SYSTEM FOR SHORT-DURATION HIGHWAY WORK ZONES" - Application No.: 17/685,605. This research has resulted in six high-impact journal articles, two under review, and three peer-reviewed conference papers, including the best demo award in the International Conference in Cyber-Physical Systems (ICCPS 2023) conference, the premier conference in CPS, and a paper featured in ASCE'sASCE's collection on Emerging Technologies Impacting the Future of Transportation Automation. This project provides new insight and knowledge on safety, including contributing factors, risk assessment, and technologies to mitigate high fatalities and injuries in highway work zones. 

The results, software, and data have been pronounced in this research and have all been disseminated to the broad research community, including:

  1. DeepTrack: https://github.com/TeCSAR-UNCC/DeepTrack_TrajectoryPrediction

  2. Pishgu: https://github.com/TeCSAR-UNCC/Pishgu 

  3. PishguVe: https://github.com/TeCSAR-UNCC/PiszhguVe

  4. Carolinas Highway Dataset (CHD): https://github.com/TeCSAR-UNCC/Carolinas_Dataset

This project has enabled significant opportunities for professional development, including advising two PhD students and two Master's students who are directly working on the project. Additionally, a senior design project involving five senior undergraduate students is focused on the research and development of our technology. Furthermore, the course has pronounced impacts on teaching and educational resources. PI Tabkhi has led two senior design projects involving undergraduate students directly in the design and development of AI aspects of the project. In addition, many principles and concepts discovered and designed to achieve the objective research goals of this project have been introduced in new undergraduate courses to the broader group of undergraduate students within the electrical and computer engineering disciplines. One clear example is discussing real-time behavior detection, trajectory analysis, prediction, and anomaly detection in the "Real-time Machine Learning course".

Overall, this project created a new generation of smart work zone systems equipped with real-time AI processing and augmented reality technology for on-the-spot worker notification. When put into practice, the project's results will significantly reduce these harrowing figures, significantly enhancing highway safety for workers.
